9ebc6310-2aa3-4598-96cc-0afcde02a711.content: {Beliefs are often interconnected in a structured way}, {The strength of a belief is influenced by its connections to other beliefs}

276dc15e-58e7-4f02-89f0-e3bce9446121.content: {Beliefs are often justified based on inference from other beliefs}, {Inferential links among beliefs contribute to their justification}

ebea0adb-1dae-455e-9fc7-aceccb097153.content: {Individuals tend to seek coherence in their belief systems}, {Psychological discomfort arises from holding incoherent beliefs}

661226d9-354d-4e38-b678-12feb2a8888e.content: {Moral beliefs are often judged by their coherence with established moral principles}, {Coherence in moral views contributes to their acceptance}

07e3b78c-5060-466a-9f48-d7b7a8df2840.content: {Explanations are often preferred when they form a coherent narrative}, {Cohesive stories are more persuasive and comprehensible}

76687c2e-f285-454a-8d8c-7cbba095d9cb.content: {Many historical beliefs are accepted based on coherence with documented evidence}, {Historical understanding is built from a coherent integration of sources}

b7a1c3da-b509-4d53-a48f-793f42451a23.content: {Cognitive dissonance occurs when beliefs are incoherent}, {People strive to resolve dissonance to restore coherence}

f46cb701-216f-49ac-ae11-d06737ccdf75.content: {Holistic understanding often demands coherence among propositions}, {Comprehensive views rely on coherence for explanatory power}

c41b4c4a-b854-4b3e-96ff-0b8d146d60c8.content: {Successful rational debate often requires coherence of arguments}, {Coherence in arguments leads to more persuasive conclusions}

17b75775-d237-4fe5-a9e5-048b5771f812.content: {Theoretical frameworks are often evaluated based on internal coherence}, {Coherence contributes to the credibility of a theoretical framework}

a6e60dd8-f736-4ffe-a1ef-8cf2b127e8ed.content: {Belief requires justification}, {Justification must be accessible to the believer}

5679e71d-6c12-4d02-9dd7-b651aa3d6ed4.content: {Introspection allows access to beliefs}, {Introspection provides a method to examine justification}

eff201ba-e4c1-4931-b78b-c94a617bc487.summary: Rational evaluation is key to justification
eff201ba-e4c1-4931-b78b-c94a617bc487.content: {Rational evaluation can determine the validity of beliefs}, {Justification involves rational assessment}

63887707-4617-426e-8814-5aa394e8a552.content: {People have immediate awareness of their own mental states}, {This awareness plays a role in justifying beliefs}

e6590afe-173e-4df1-93eb-4ae70071ee82.content: {Some beliefs appear self-evident through reflection}, {Self-evidence contributes to justification}

19949ee1-0c13-4070-8a6b-1a7bb653dc5d.content: {Cognitive processes are scrutinized for coherence}, {Coherent cognitive processes ensure justified beliefs}

0ff3aae9-703d-4b2a-884c-fac4b2b23187.content: {Mental states are interconnected}, {Coherence of mental states affects justification of beliefs}

f9df6819-4bca-4b2e-a504-e563d9586ee2.content: {Internal mental states are involved in forming beliefs}, {Justification relies on accessibility of these states}

e498faf8-c83b-4922-80bc-d9adf9950c1a.content: {Perceptual experiences provide information}, {This information justifies belief}

6b1c8b31-13d1-4c11-b28e-6c9654987989.content: {Memory provides access to past experiences}, {Past experiences help in justifying current beliefs}

29a5efaf-cd09-47a6-bae0-bd684bd7aab7.content: {Conscious reflection evaluates beliefs}, {This evaluation process is part of justification}

71352a7c-f138-4d9d-81ef-a948ec887741.summary: Intuition plays a role in justification
71352a7c-f138-4d9d-81ef-a948ec887741.content: {Intuitions can provide immediate understanding}, {Such understanding helps justify beliefs}

f76c8d4b-0303-41a9-ae7a-f1982a377c5e.summary: Clarity of concepts is necessary for justification
f76c8d4b-0303-41a9-ae7a-f1982a377c5e.content: {Clear concepts contribute to understanding}, {Understanding supports the justification of beliefs}

44c9ae92-ca74-4d6a-bc27-314991c479ec.summary: Epistemic responsibility involves checking belief justification
44c9ae92-ca74-4d6a-bc27-314991c479ec.content: {Individuals are responsible for their beliefs}, {This responsibility includes ensuring beliefs are justified}

a54729db-7245-4451-a156-c026fcb54339.content: {Belief justification varies with context}, {Context determines what information is accessible for justification}

e5a8d153-7241-4e52-b88e-beeed9195ac4.summary: Access to reasons strengthens belief justification
e5a8d153-7241-4e52-b88e-beeed9195ac4.content: {Having access to reasons supports belief}, {Access to these reasons enhances justification}

5065aa7c-c0bc-4aef-92ec-e862f5336758.summary: Internal reflection aids in evaluating belief validity
5065aa7c-c0bc-4aef-92ec-e862f5336758.content: {Internal reflection assesses belief validity}, {This assessment contributes to the justification process}

5fcbb451-41ec-4704-950a-be08038fdec4.content: {A person can only know a proposition if it is true}, {A belief does not constitute knowledge if the proposition believed is false}

7a19a521-1c5f-4e62-8bdc-85754637be2f.content: {Knowledge requires that an individual holds a belief in the proposition}, {Without belief, even true propositions cannot be known}

9665e2a7-260e-4c79-ba8f-1100e1f21d1e.content: {External factors can play a role in justifying a belief}, {A person’s mental states are not the only determinants of knowledge justification}

2777b3d9-b2f9-407f-85b7-0cfc394e6ebf.content: {An external source that reliably produces true beliefs contributes to knowing}, {Reliability of a process can justify belief independently of internal states}

dabda91f-4cdd-4adf-810b-41d25be82948.content: {There can be a causal connection between believing a proposition and its truth}, {This causal link can serve as a form of justification for knowledge}

6f03cf7a-e646-41d1-8802-a98783531843.content: {An individual’s environment can contribute to the accuracy of beliefs}, {Knowledge can be dependent on factors present in the external environment}

daaa9be6-b336-442f-a081-cca9ec04553b.content: {Access to external information affects the justification of a belief}, {External sources provide evidence that can validate a belief as knowledge}

c5868436-2e0b-422b-8448-59b5591525d2.content: {Social and cultural contexts can influence what is considered justified belief}, {Knowledge may depend on external social factors}

be0207d3-dbc5-45ed-ba2c-4bea9035012c.content: {Perception of external objects contributes to the justification of beliefs}, {External objects can provide direct evidence for knowledge claims}

38a516f1-bb76-4640-919b-65af99c95889.content: {Knowledge standards can be shaped by community agreement}, {Justification of beliefs may rely on communal evaluation rather than solely individual mental states}

e72c2723-d11c-4185-8b99-f470ba44437f.summary: Knowledge involves information that can be stored
e72c2723-d11c-4185-8b99-f470ba44437f.content: {Knowledge is a type of information}, {Information can be differentiated and stored}, {Storing information is crucial for processing knowledge}

bf1c5e7c-b1f1-46a6-91a3-be60cc5d9fc1.content: {Knowledge reduces uncertainty}, {Reducing uncertainty enhances decision-making}, {Decision-making improves with reliable information}

06a7d25b-b093-4159-91a1-36728fcb2cb0.summary: True information affects how we understand reality
06a7d25b-b093-4159-91a1-36728fcb2cb0.content: {Knowledge is constituted by true information}, {True information alters our understanding of the world}, {An altered understanding of the world leads to better predictions}

2d6a5caa-9c91-4c88-bd98-9fd8cdcdc245.summary: Information requires a degree of reliability to be considered knowledge
2d6a5caa-9c91-4c88-bd98-9fd8cdcdc245.content: {Reliable information is necessary for knowledge}, {Unreliable information leads to false beliefs}, {False beliefs hinder effective action}

695549d8-8159-4e63-9d69-a94efe9baeb8.content: {Information is central to learning}, {Learning requires the accumulation and processing of information}, {Adaptation results from learning and the assimilation of new information}

df606a36-55dc-4a5e-b778-e5bddbe62092.content: {Communication involves transmitting knowledge}, {Shared information facilitates mutual understanding}, {Mutual understanding is essential for cooperative activities}

575941c7-26d8-4f73-b9eb-c3cab4624dd5.content: {Knowledge enhances the ability to predict}, {Predictions rely on accurate information}, {Accurate predictions guide future actions effectively}

77e41319-4e4c-4117-8272-726fb3f47c6a.summary: Cognitive development involves increasing one’s store of information
77e41319-4e4c-4117-8272-726fb3f47c6a.content: {Cognitive development is tied to growing knowledge}, {Growth in knowledge expands the store of information}, {Expanding the store of information enhances cognitive abilities}

f2f951e2-58fc-48cd-937b-cf01f6b027b2.summary: Relevant information leads to effective problem-solving
f2f951e2-58fc-48cd-937b-cf01f6b027b2.content: {Problem-solving requires knowledge}, {Knowledge involves relevant information}, {Effective problem-solving depends on access to relevant information}

ced00e8c-2594-452e-85c1-a084eba39b30.summary: Knowledge allows for abstraction and generalization
ced00e8c-2594-452e-85c1-a084eba39b30.content: {Knowledge includes abstract concepts}, {Abstract concepts are derived from accumulated information}, {Generalization relies on synthesizing information from different contexts}

de604e30-85ee-4e34-9b45-73667eee0896.summary: Reliable information is necessary for trust in knowledge claims
de604e30-85ee-4e34-9b45-73667eee0896.content: {Trust in knowledge depends on reliability}, {Reliability is ensured by consistent information}, {Inconsistent information breeds doubt about knowledge claims}

e02179e1-e4fb-48d7-ba2b-18f8669a2950.summary: Access to diverse information influences creativity
e02179e1-e4fb-48d7-ba2b-18f8669a2950.content: {Creativity is linked to knowledge}, {Diverse information encourages novel connections and ideas}, {Novel connections and ideas foster creative outcomes}

ed1110ca-baca-4fa8-bc05-249250c10d27.summary: Reliable information serves as a foundation for technological progress
ed1110ca-baca-4fa8-bc05-249250c10d27.content: {Technology relies on sound knowledge}, {Sound knowledge stems from reliable information}, {Technological progress builds upon a robust foundation of information}

a22453cf-d01f-48ef-bc6c-69582d06308b.content: {When a person's perception aligns with the actual state of affairs, it results in immediate knowledge}, {Accurate perceptions do not require inferential justification to yield knowledge}

a6c2a2ae-180e-4604-878c-cf1b3102916a.content: {Genuine perceptual experiences provide a direct connection to the world}, {This direct connection is sufficient for perceptual knowledge when the experience is true}

4b421143-c843-449a-a548-4a1c21d2408d.content: {Veridical perception and hallucination are distinct}, {This distinction is significant because only veridical perception can lead directly to knowledge}

5dee094d-b8f5-46fa-8983-97cfe2251233.content: {Accurate perception has a unique epistemic status compared to inaccurate perception}, {This unique status allows accurate perception to result directly in knowledge}

bf4014e5-e652-478d-afe5-16d0d758a2c0.content: {Perceptual knowledge does not require further evidence beyond the percept itself}, {This directness differentiates perceptual knowledge from inferential knowledge}

9b435696-e83d-4ef7-8724-5d17e0916ee1.content: {Accurate perceptual experiences provide immediate awareness of the environment}, {This immediate awareness constitutes knowledge without intermediary reasoning}

18da84c7-bfd5-456b-b0b1-b3141419cbf1.content: {Perceptual experiences, when reliable, provide the subject with accurate information}, {The reliability of perception grounds its ability to function as a source of knowledge}

245faa57-1726-4d61-8b38-4ac31688cb09.content: {Veridical, or truthful, perception cannot be wrong about its content}, {This infallibility is what makes veridical perception a direct source of knowledge}

ae3f4378-fd00-4486-95a6-be3bedb1349a.content: {Perceptual knowledge cannot be reduced to other forms of knowledge}, {This irreducibility supports the directness of perception as a knowledge source}

4cb8a236-6da1-4536-9c71-d75f2c449742.content: {Authentic, accurate perception lays the groundwork for other knowledge}, {This foundational role underpins its direct connection to knowledge}

4872ef88-36fd-4458-ae32-4632aa62f37b.summary: Perceptual experiences vary in epistemic value
4872ef88-36fd-4458-ae32-4632aa62f37b.content: {The epistemic value of perceptual experiences depends on their accuracy}, {Accurate experiences have intrinsic epistemic value, leading directly to knowledge}

20681ca1-264a-4fdf-ba9d-2d31cdaf2076.summary: Is Gettier's problem a challenge to the definition of knowledge as justified true belief?
20681ca1-264a-4fdf-ba9d-2d31cdaf2076.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has a justified belief that the time is 3 PM because they look at an accurate clock. Unbeknownst to them, the clock stopped 24 hours ago at 3 PM. Intuitively, we would judge that the person does not have knowledge even though their belief is true, justified, and they believe it.}, {A person can have a justified belief that is true without having knowledge if the belief is true by luck rather than due to the justification.}

214a6ade-b2b8-4321-bcff-aea5d92c3ae6.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person indistinctively states a correct fact without actually believing it, such as stating today's date correctly out of habit but truly thinking it is another date. Intuitively, we would judge that this person does not know the date, even though the statement is true and justified.}, {It is implausible that knowledge exists in the absence of genuine belief in the proposition.}

daf5d1e6-8d45-427b-b3ae-7bf266fb40ea.summary: Can knowledge be separated from justification if the source is unreliable?
daf5d1e6-8d45-427b-b3ae-7bf266fb40ea.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person forms a belief that it will rain based on an unreliable weather forecast, and it turns out to rain. Intuitively, we have to say that although their belief was true, the wrongdoing of the justification undermines it.}, {A true belief formed on the basis of false justification does not amount to knowledge if the reliability of the source is unacceptable.}

a2a304b7-5102-4773-ba47-036616291e0e.summary: Does knowledge require more than justified true belief in cases of coincidental truths?
a2a304b7-5102-4773-ba47-036616291e0e.content: {Consider a situation where a gambler believes that a particular horse will win a race. Their belief is based on superstition, yet the horse happens to win the race. Intuitively, we would judge that the gambler does not possess knowledge, even though their belief is true and they believe it.}, {Knowledge cannot be attributed if the truth of the belief is merely coincidental and lacks proper justification.}

4bad96f7-9934-4f80-a2c0-2397034a57f9.summary: Does the possibility of false premises in justification threaten justified true belief?
4bad96f7-9934-4f80-a2c0-2397034a57f9.content: {Consider a scenario in which a detective forms a belief that a suspect committed a crime based on several false testimonies that accidentally lead to the correct conclusion. Intuitively, we would judge that the detective does not have true knowledge of the suspect's guilt.}, {Justified true belief based on false premises does not constitute knowledge if the justification is flawed due to incorrect assumptions.}

c0a8c4c1-2e36-4370-9f15-9e924ac4f6c7.summary: Can unreliable methods producing justified true beliefs amount to knowledge?
c0a8c4c1-2e36-4370-9f15-9e924ac4f6c7.content: {Suppose a person uses a horoscope to decide that their favorite team will win the championship. The team does win, but their horoscope is not a reliable guide to the truth. Intuitively, we either have to say the person did not truly know the team would win or attribute knowledge incorrectly.}, {A method can be unreliable even if it accidentally produces justified true beliefs, implying that knowledge requires more than such coincidental accuracy.}

af41e2f9-ce4d-4cf1-89b9-67efa938d970.summary: Can new information alter the status of a justified true belief as knowledge?
af41e2f9-ce4d-4cf1-89b9-67efa938d970.content: {Consider a case where a scientist believes that a theory is true based on available evidence. Soon after, new evidence emerges that falsifies the prior justification, even though the theory still happens to be true. Intuitively, we would judge that the scientist’s previous belief does not amount to knowledge in light of the new evidence.}, {Knowledge seems to require that the justification holds up under counter-evidence, suggesting a deeper requirement than justified true belief.}

e49550af-9a16-4bf5-ab42-8e6360c02cc2.summary: Can credible misinformation challenge the notion of justified true belief as knowledge?
e49550af-9a16-4bf5-ab42-8e6360c02cc2.content: {Imagine a scenario where a person believes a credible but erroneous report about a politician's actions and fortunately this crosses with the unexpected true actions of the politician that align with the report. Intuitively, the belief does not become knowledge because of the initial misinformation.}, {Credible misinformation challenges the idea that a belief justified by falsehood can be considered knowledge even when true.}

e7f49b0c-cfab-4f13-a61b-474dbe015b76.summary: How can 'No False Lemmas' account for knowledge without excluding cases of legitimate knowledge?
e7f49b0c-cfab-4f13-a61b-474dbe015b76.content: {A case in which a person has a justified true belief that a proposition is true, but this belief is based on an assumption that is not directly related to the truth of the proposition in question, challenges the requirement that no false assumptions are involved.}, {Intuitively, we might still judge that the person knows the proposition even if the unrelated assumption is false.}

e73845ff-a905-4d83-a61b-571c5e7bad50.summary: Does 'No False Lemmas' handle Gettier-type problems sufficiently?
e73845ff-a905-4d83-a61b-571c5e7bad50.content: {Consider a scenario where someone forms a belief based on evidence that is true by coincidence even when some assumptions in forming the belief are false.}, {In such a scenario, their justified true belief appears to contradict the 'No False Lemmas' requirement, yet it intuitively feels like they possess knowledge.}

964732ce-6155-452a-afe1-3410a9f2e2af.summary: Can 'No False Lemmas' explain cases where someone has a justified true belief based on reliable evidence but still includes false assumptions?
964732ce-6155-452a-afe1-3410a9f2e2af.content: {A case where a person uses reliable evidence to form a justified true belief but relies on a minor false assumption unrelated to the main proposition seems to challenge the 'No False Lemmas' requirement.}, {The proposition could intuitively still be classified as knowledge despite the false assumption.}

fc9ead46-10f4-4678-af49-0ae1716f1f31.summary: Does 'No False Lemmas' align with our intuitive understanding of knowledge when assumptions are minor and irrelevant?
fc9ead46-10f4-4678-af49-0ae1716f1f31.content: {Suppose there is a case where a person holds a justified true belief supported by major true assumptions but includes insignificant false assumptions.}, {Despite the false assumptions, intuitively, we might judge that the person still knows the proposition.}

c170ba88-576b-426b-a6f0-9413ef6f3009.summary: How does 'No False Lemmas' handle scenarios where knowledge seems evident but is based on misleading initial evidence?
c170ba88-576b-426b-a6f0-9413ef6f3009.content: {A scenario where the truth of a belief is established from misleading evidence but the conclusion is correct suggests an issue with 'No False Lemmas.'}, {Intuitively, even with initial false assumptions, we might still recognize the belief as knowledge.}

bfedcbde-cb1f-4ef4-ac11-fe0b068a1c6a.summary: Does 'No False Lemmas' accommodate knowledge cases involving infallible evidence but inaccurate background assumptions?
bfedcbde-cb1f-4ef4-ac11-fe0b068a1c6a.content: {Consider a person who forms a justified true belief using infallible evidence yet holds inaccurate background assumptions.}, {Intuitively, we might consider the person knowledgeable despite the inaccurate assumptions.}

3bd20f67-5b69-4bcf-a930-2847f57768e5.summary: How does 'No False Lemmas' account for cases where erroneous assumptions do not directly affect the truth of a conclusion?
3bd20f67-5b69-4bcf-a930-2847f57768e5.content: {Suppose there’s a situation where someone has a justified true belief where their false assumptions are peripheral and don't affect the truth of the belief.}, {We might intuitively judge that the person still knows the proposition despite the minor false assumptions.}

6a5c6bcb-8546-4088-93fb-becf2497d4a2.summary: Does 'No False Lemmas' misclassify knowledge by dismissing beliefs with true conclusions derived from complex chains of reasoning with false premises?
6a5c6bcb-8546-4088-93fb-becf2497d4a2.content: {Consider an individual who derives a complex chain of reasoning with some false premises but still reaches a true conclusion that is justified.}, {Intuitively, we may still regard the individual as having knowledge even though the view implies they lack it due to the false premises.}

c0c23d19-2dac-4ad2-a5dc-755f7ccb06bc.summary: Is it possible to know something without a causal connection to the fact?
c0c23d19-2dac-4ad2-a5dc-755f7ccb06bc.content: {A case exists where a person forms a belief just by luck, and the belief is true.}, {If a belief is true only by luck, it is not intuitive that the person knows it.}

f96f46b1-18ea-41c9-ac75-45e67cb3f904.summary: Can causal chains be undermined by misleading information?
f96f46b1-18ea-41c9-ac75-45e67cb3f904.content: {A person may believe a true proposition based on misleading evidence that is causally connected to a fact.}, {A person who believes a true proposition due to misleading evidence does not seem to have knowledge.}

c5cd9126-9892-471f-8ab6-25053874a636.summary: Does incorrect causal reasoning invalidate knowledge claims?
c5cd9126-9892-471f-8ab6-25053874a636.content: {In a scenario where a person has a belief based on incorrect reasoning but the belief is true, the causal chain might be faulty.}, {A belief based on incorrect reasoning seems not to qualify as knowledge, even if causally connected.}

bc111e20-d385-4e3e-a96c-e66c82b458c1.summary: Are there too many causal connections to consider?
bc111e20-d385-4e3e-a96c-e66c82b458c1.content: {A true proposition can have multiple causal connections, both direct and indirect, leading to a belief.}, {Knowing how to delineate the "right" causal connection seems difficult and possibly unmanageable.}

c62f2dee-ea43-46f9-80f1-0068a446cec9.content: {There exists a case where a person is presented with a true fact but does not form a belief.}, {Even without belief, it seems possible for a person to act as if they have knowledge.}

b09c44bd-3f91-4f62-8e47-69ac46cd1dff.summary: Does a causal link ensure reliability in belief formation?
b09c44bd-3f91-4f62-8e47-69ac46cd1dff.content: {Reliability typically requires consistent and repeatable success in forming beliefs.}, {A single causal link does not necessarily provide the reliability required for knowledge.}

43484cb3-4663-41fb-8a55-329b0608178e.summary: Does knowing how something happened imply knowledge of the outcome?
43484cb3-4663-41fb-8a55-329b0608178e.content: {A person might understand the causal process leading to an event but have no belief in its outcome.}, {Without belief in the outcome itself, a person does not intuitively possess knowledge of the outcome.}

adb95162-571f-4951-a649-efc3d92654d3.summary: Can causal chains fail through indirect methods?
adb95162-571f-4951-a649-efc3d92654d3.content: {A person might believe a true proposition due to indirect transmission of information, like rumor or hearsay.}, {If a person believes based purely on hearsay, they lack direct causal connection to the facts.}

e4ec230a-ad08-47b9-ac74-d1020989b519.content: {Introspective knowledge includes beliefs about one's own mental states.}, {Introspective knowledge seems not to require an external causal connection to be valid.}

b048a828-cc8f-4ba9-bcaf-378f13bc7018.summary: Can a causal pathway be fortuitous?
b048a828-cc8f-4ba9-bcaf-378f13bc7018.content: {A person can arrive at a true belief through a complex series of events that appears accidental.}, {A belief that arises from what seems to be an accident does not intuitively seem to qualify as knowledge.}

d8045794-eb1e-437d-917d-07df25f9d009.content: {Visual illusions can lead to beliefs about true propositions through faulty perceptual processes.}, {If perception is misleading, the belief does not intuitively qualify as knowledge despite a causal link.}

8148c479-8277-46aa-980f-dd1bf3bf2789.summary: Is every true belief with a causal history knowledge?
8148c479-8277-46aa-980f-dd1bf3bf2789.content: {A person might form various true beliefs, each with its causal history.}, {Despite a causal history, not all true beliefs seem to meet the standards of knowledge.}

b80e5d34-b096-4fb2-ba96-01cf786c9ad0.summary: Is memory as a causal link reliable enough for knowledge?
b80e5d34-b096-4fb2-ba96-01cf786c9ad0.content: {Memory can serve as a causal link between the occurrence of a fact and the belief of a proposition.}, {Given that memories can be unreliable, not every belief formed from memory intuitively constitutes knowledge.}

3ff62479-9549-4f04-b69f-c2306a1d5e43.summary: Are hallucinations a challenge in causal connections?
3ff62479-9549-4f04-b69f-c2306a1d5e43.content: {Someone might have a vivid hallucination that relates to a true state of affairs, thus forming a belief.}, {Despite the true proposition, the hallucinatory basis causes a valid suspicion regarding this being knowledge.}

279feecd-d740-4158-9f7f-e0ef145cf1a1.summary: Does knowing a proposition entail knowing related propositions?
279feecd-d740-4158-9f7f-e0ef145cf1a1.content: {A person might accurately know that it is raining, which causally links to the fact.}, {That person might not know related facts, like how rain occurs, casting doubt on the completeness of knowledge.}

43b4ebdf-e9ba-4642-9e80-dd06914696b6.summary: Can a belief formed by chance still qualify as knowledge under reliabilism?
43b4ebdf-e9ba-4642-9e80-dd06914696b6.content: {A person forms a belief that it will rain tomorrow by flipping a coin. It is true that it will rain tomorrow. Intuitively, this is not a case of knowledge.}, {The process of flipping a coin is not a reliable process for forming true beliefs about the weather. Thus, this belief lacks reliability.}

82af890d-ba5c-4b82-87df-08a67e78288b.summary: Does reliabilism account for the problem of cognitive malfunction or breakdown?
82af890d-ba5c-4b82-87df-08a67e78288b.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person's usual reliable cognitive process malfunctions, leading them to form a true belief. Despite the truth, intuitively, we do not judge this as knowledge.}, {A cognitive process, when malfunctioning, may produce true beliefs, but these cases typically lack reliability.}

b3d9e558-239f-4f91-8120-2f3d53b59c8a.summary: Can reliabilism handle cases where the reliability of a process changes over time?
b3d9e558-239f-4f91-8120-2f3d53b59c8a.content: {Suppose a belief-forming process starts as unreliable but gradually becomes reliable as a person gains experience. During the transitional phase, it is unclear if the process is reliable enough for the beliefs to count as knowledge.}, {If a process's reliability fluctuates, determining the point at which beliefs count as knowledge becomes problematic within reliabilism.}

6138d828-fcae-432b-a0d8-986ab70e7408.summary: How does reliabilism address the new evil demon problem?
6138d828-fcae-432b-a0d8-986ab70e7408.content: {Imagine a scenario where an evil demon makes all your beliefs false, though they are formed through processes that are generally reliable in a normal world. Intuitively, we might still consider these beliefs justified, yet they are not true, challenging the reliabilist link between reliability and justification.}, {A reliabilist account must explain how to reconcile reliability in an "evil demon world" when the beliefs formed are false due to external factors.}

455bfc74-9b01-45b5-940d-0b6b6380edf1.summary: Is unreflective access to the reliability of a belief-forming process problematic for reliabilism?
455bfc74-9b01-45b5-940d-0b6b6380edf1.content: {Consider a person who forms true beliefs by a reliable process without being aware of the process's reliability. Intuitively, we might question whether these beliefs truly count as knowledge, given the lack of awareness.}, {Reliabilism suggests that having knowledge does not require awareness of the reliability of the belief-forming process, which can conflict with intuitions requiring some cognitive access.}

3a2af396-1f74-483f-ab99-f8fc67c5347d.summary: Does reliabilism address the generality problem adequately?
3a2af396-1f74-483f-ab99-f8fc67c5347d.content: {The generality problem arises in determining the 'type' of process a belief belongs to when evaluating its reliability. If a belief can be categorized under multiple processes, each with different reliability levels, identifying the correct process becomes problematic.}, {Reliabilism relies on the ability to classify processes correctly to assess reliability, but multiple plausible categorizations complicate this.}

20b342fb-5780-407f-8dd6-14fabc88202a.summary: Can reliabilism distinguish between knowledge and accidentally true beliefs?
20b342fb-5780-407f-8dd6-14fabc88202a.content: {Suppose a person randomly guesses a true proposition without any reliable method. Intuitively, we would not consider this knowledge, as the truth was a matter of luck rather than a reliable process.}, {Reliabilism struggles with cases where true beliefs arise purely by chance, questioning whether reliance on process alone suffices for knowledge.}

21a67080-891c-4d04-a73a-dfdd057763ba.summary: How does reliabilism accommodate situations where environmental factors skew reliability?
21a67080-891c-4d04-a73a-dfdd057763ba.content: {Imagine a situation where external factors, such as misleading information or altered environments, affect the reliability of a normally dependable process. In such cases, beliefs may lose reliability due to situational changes, challenging the constancy presumed by reliabilism.}, {Assessing reliability requires considering environmental variables which can alter the usual performance of belief-forming processes.}

a1fe3078-5f29-4ab6-acd7-97de7124c37c.summary: Can one truly know something if justified false beliefs exist?
a1fe3078-5f29-4ab6-acd7-97de7124c37c.content: {Consider a scenario where a person believes a false proposition due to a reliable cognitive process. Intuitively, we would judge that being so misled still means the belief lacks truth.}, {It is implausible that a belief about a false proposition could be considered knowledge.}

342c8d8c-ef77-42b6-ad96-78c721befa20.summary: Could there be knowledge without a belief in the truth?
342c8d8c-ef77-42b6-ad96-78c721befa20.content: {Suppose a person holds a true proposition accidentally rather than as a result of a robust belief-forming process. Intuitively, this seems like a case where the person lacks genuine belief.}, {It is implausible that a person can know a proposition without sincerely believing it.}

67c09711-39ea-4f8f-b4cd-d0a92bedeb4a.summary: Is it possible for someone to track truth without knowing?
67c09711-39ea-4f8f-b4cd-d0a92bedeb4a.content: {Suppose a case where a person correctly believes a true proposition but lacks understanding of why it is true. Intuitively, we would not attribute knowledge to them despite the true belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge requires understanding in addition to true belief.}

51442c2f-8e89-4dc7-b7b1-6fdd2ea1d03a.summary: Can knowledge exist if beliefs persist despite counterfactual changes?
51442c2f-8e89-4dc7-b7b1-6fdd2ea1d03a.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person's true belief in a proposition persists even if the proposition turns false due to irrational stubbornness. Intuitively, we would not attribute knowledge in this case, despite fulfilling the truth condition.}, {It is implausible that irrational persistence of belief can qualify as knowledge.}

37ca7c40-4fe2-4056-84ef-b9bd006fad30.summary: Do cases of epistemic luck undermine the possibility of knowing?
37ca7c40-4fe2-4056-84ef-b9bd006fad30.content: {Consider a case where a person intends to believe a false proposition but accidentally ends up believing something true due to sheer luck. Intuitively, we do not regard this as knowledge despite the truth of the belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge cannot be a matter of luck alone, but must instead involve a reliable process.}

405d539f-ff99-4037-b098-d6d52c93a18a.summary: Is the truth-tracking condition necessary for knowledge?
405d539f-ff99-4037-b098-d6d52c93a18a.content: {Consider a scenario where a person's belief turns out true, but their belief-forming methods are not truth-sensitive. Intuitively, such a scenario seems to lack genuine knowledge.}, {It is implausible that knowing requires only coincidental truth, without a reliable method of belief-formation.}

c44133d3-c97f-43ae-a909-4bb813707226.summary: Could there be a scenario where belief adjustment defeats truth-tracking?
c44133d3-c97f-43ae-a909-4bb813707226.content: {Suppose a person adjusts a belief based on unreliable evidence, such that the belief is true, but would change if the proposition were otherwise falsely portrayed. Intuitively, such fluctuating beliefs do not amount to knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that reliable belief adjustment is crucial to knowing rather than mere coincidence of truth.}

d8ef4919-f9e4-4c1b-a358-e595aef58a80.summary: Are there scenarios that fit the conditions of truth-tracking yet fail to be knowledge?
d8ef4919-f9e4-4c1b-a358-e595aef58a80.content: {Imagine a situation where a person's belief is formed in a misleading context, yet by chance, happens to track the truth accurately. Intuitively, we hesitate to affirm this as knowledge due to the unreliable context.}, {It is implausible that knowledge can be based on unreliable processes even if the outcome tracks truth.}

e3c93759-bd85-416c-a7e2-5165526d2459.summary: Could epistemic fallibility challenge the coherence of truth-tracking?
e3c93759-bd85-416c-a7e2-5165526d2459.content: {Imagine a scenario where multiple plausible beliefs tracking truth fall in conflict upon new evidence, rendering knowledge uncertain. Intuitively, such conflict suggests knowledge is not strictly dependent on initial truth-tracking.}, {It is plausible that knowledge requires more than mere consistency with truth across counterfactual changes.}

dee14389-8cf1-4336-bdb9-262ba79f7000.summary: Might knowledge require a degree of certainty beyond truth-tracking?
dee14389-8cf1-4336-bdb9-262ba79f7000.content: {Suppose a person accurately tracks the truth of a proposition, but remains doubtful of their own beliefs. Intuitively, such doubt seems to preclude the status of knowledge, regardless of correctness.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge entails a level of psychological certainty along with truth.}

7a975292-6d33-4603-9444-5e1c2ac23ba5.summary: Can virtuous character generate true belief without luck?
7a975292-6d33-4603-9444-5e1c2ac23ba5.content: {Consider a scenario where a person forms a belief through an intellectual virtue, but, by chance, the belief turns out to be true due to unforeseen factors, such as a misleading environment. Intuitively, we would judge that the person does not truly know the proposition despite the virtue being involved.}, {It is plausible to say that knowledge requires more than a true belief resulting from intellectual virtue because external factors or luck can contribute to the truth.}

20cca902-2b14-46ff-9996-e5d812f8f48d.summary: Does intellectual virtue always result in knowledge?
20cca902-2b14-46ff-9996-e5d812f8f48d.content: {Suppose we consider a case where a person uses an intellectual virtue to form a belief, but the person lacks understanding of the broader context, like mistaking a realistic movie for a documentary. Intuitively, we might have to say the person believes correctly but does not have knowledge.}, {It is implausible that intellectual virtue alone suffices for knowledge because understanding and appreciation of context might also be necessary.}

5a104469-b425-4074-86fb-b885aa36461e.summary: Are intellectual virtues sufficient without considering epistemic responsibility?
5a104469-b425-4074-86fb-b885aa36461e.content: {Imagine a scenario where a person forms a true belief through intellectual virtue, yet carelessly disregards relevant evidence that would normally be evaluated. Intuitively, it seems incorrect to attribute knowledge to this person due to their epistemic irresponsibility.}, {There is a plausible principle that epistemic responsibility is critical for knowledge, which implies that intellectual virtues are insufficient on their own.}

e7a64fe3-8d58-46a6-85b5-0ea3f389e79f.summary: Can knowledge be detached from the justification of belief?
e7a64fe3-8d58-46a6-85b5-0ea3f389e79f.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person believes a true proposition solely through intellectual virtue, without any conscious justification or reasoning process. Intuitively, we might find it odd to consider this genuine knowledge because the person cannot articulate reasons for their belief.}, {A plausible principle is that knowledge should be connected to justification, suggesting that the role of intellectual virtues must be accompanied by a justificatory process.}

2f769a34-f0cc-4e29-ba2a-a71f92441ba4.summary: How does unconscious intellect relate to knowledge?
2f769a34-f0cc-4e29-ba2a-a71f92441ba4.content: {Consider an example where a person, through unconscious intellectual virtue, arrives at a true belief but cannot explain or reflect on how they achieved it, like an intuitive but non-reflective insight. Intuitively, it seems that without conscious awareness or reflection, knowledge attribution is problematic.}, {It is implausible that involuntary or unconscious elements can fulfill the knowledge requirement because reflective access and understanding are often seen as essential.}

2ac8f3ff-4483-4666-bfb1-c32f312a23ca.summary: Can varying standards for knowledge lead to contradictions?
2ac8f3ff-4483-4666-bfb1-c32f312a23ca.content: {There is a plausible principle that if standards for knowledge vary across contexts, then a proposition could be known in one context but not known in another.}, {A person could sincerely state that they know a proposition in a low-standard context and deny knowing the same proposition in a high-standard context, leading to a contradiction.}

398b6636-de8b-4c87-b686-1377c4fda4c4.summary: Does contextualism allow for excessive skepticism?
398b6636-de8b-4c87-b686-1377c4fda4c4.content: {Contextualism implies that in some contexts, the standards for knowing could be set so high that no proposition could be known.}, {If knowledge is impossible in certain skeptical contexts, it seems implausible for us ever to claim knowledge without deferring to less skeptical contexts, which undermines our ordinary claims to know.}

9dc8251f-6ff5-4168-85b9-128eba2a82e5.summary: Can contextualism lead to confusion about what is known?
9dc8251f-6ff5-4168-85b9-128eba2a82e5.content: {Suppose a person claims to know something in a casual setting but refrains from claiming to know the same thing in an academic setting due to higher standards.}, {It becomes unclear and confusing what the person truly knows if knowledge statements change based on the context and may lead to miscommunication or misunderstanding.}

23bf9ab6-20c2-46d9-a942-5f782d2a7c52.summary: Does contextualism make inter-contextual communication challenging?
23bf9ab6-20c2-46d9-a942-5f782d2a7c52.content: {There is a plausible principle that in order for communication to be successful, interlocutors must agree on what constitutes knowledge.}, {If the standards for knowledge vary significantly between contexts, then individuals may find it challenging to communicate effectively about what is known.}

7a0dd1dc-ab3a-4805-aad3-053570c9d059.content: {Suppose philosophers discuss a problem, each applying different contextual standards for knowledge.}, {If contextual standards vary too much, no consensus about what is known or not known can be reached, undermining the pursuit of philosophical knowledge.}

9458f6c0-ddc2-4692-97aa-59fa2760c7eb.content: {The view that knowledge standards vary across contexts suggests that what one person knows could vary significantly from what another person knows based merely on context.}, {Such variability might lead to a form of epistemic relativism, where knowledge loses its objective status and becomes relative to contextual factors.}

aea27d04-3c0c-4eaa-a7ee-a03fbb7e23f3.summary: Does contextualism obscure the nature of truth?
aea27d04-3c0c-4eaa-a7ee-a03fbb7e23f3.content: {Suppose truth in one context means adhering to different standards than another context.}, {This variability could confuse or obscure the objective nature of truth, as what is considered true might change drastically based on contextual factors.}

7903ba3f-f3a9-47af-a4d5-c3e7485d5584.summary: Can contextualism result in regulatory inconsistencies?
7903ba3f-f3a9-47af-a4d5-c3e7485d5584.content: {There is a plausible principle that regulatory frameworks, such as legal standards, require consistent application of knowledge standards.}, {If the standards for knowledge vary across contexts, applying a consistent and fair regulatory or legal framework becomes problematic and potentially unjust.}

2e2ef6a5-d421-4a95-bcb2-5c326d247e54.content: {Suppose in a low-standard context, a person claims to know something and acts upon it, whereas in a high-standard context, they deny knowing it if consequences arise.}, {This creates a loophole where individuals can escape accountability by shifting contexts and thereby altering their knowledge claims.}

3cd227ce-7763-4ac9-82e2-75aa8618ff63.content: {Epistemology seeks to understand and analyze knowledge claims clearly and systematically.}, {By introducing varying standards for knowledge, contextualism adds complexity that may hinder a straightforward analysis of what constitutes knowledge.}

dbb6b5a5-7a29-4b4b-a58f-f1834ee7dba0.summary: Can knowledge be practical if it doesn't lead to action?
dbb6b5a5-7a29-4b4b-a58f-f1834ee7dba0.content: {Consider a scenario where a person knows a proposition such as a mathematical theorem that does not directly guide any action. Intuitively, we would still claim that the person has knowledge even though it guides no action.}, {It is implausible that knowledge is solely practical if certain forms of knowledge, like theoretical knowledge, do not lead to immediate action.}

869919cb-0605-4f88-bb62-a6da00001d86.summary: Does all knowledge always lead to successful action?
869919cb-0605-4f88-bb62-a6da00001d86.content: {There is a plausible principle that even well-grounded and justified knowledge can sometimes guide unsuccessful actions due to unforeseen variables.}, {Consider a situation where a person knows the weather forecast is for clear skies but an unexpected storm causes their planned picnic to fail. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual still had knowledge despite it not leading to successful action.}

0002cbe5-495c-41a9-b357-a1eaed41ba67.summary: Can propositional knowledge exist without being action-guiding?
0002cbe5-495c-41a9-b357-a1eaed41ba67.content: {Consider a scenario where a person knows a historical fact about ancient civilizations that does not influence or guide present action. Intuitively, we would still judge that the person knows the fact.}, {It is implausible that all propositional knowledge must necessarily guide action, as some knowledge serves primarily as information without practical application.}

ecc3c338-a912-408b-bc8e-6066b1e9307f.summary: How does pragmatic knowledge apply to moral propositions?
ecc3c338-a912-408b-bc8e-6066b1e9307f.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person knows a moral proposition, such as that it is wrong to harm others, but chooses not to act on it due to conflicting desires. Intuitively, either we have to say that they still possess moral knowledge or that moral knowledge vanished with inaction. If we say they still possess moral knowledge, then knowledge does not strictly guide action.}

5cd1b951-77ed-4795-b49f-8fdb6a87b7ec.summary: What if practical knowledge clashes with ethical considerations?
5cd1b951-77ed-4795-b49f-8fdb6a87b7ec.content: {Suppose a person knows how to achieve a successful action that is ethically questionable, like deceiving someone to gain a benefit. Intuitively, we either have to say that they possess knowledge or not, regardless of ethical outcomes. If we say they possess knowledge, then such knowledge may not always align with what is ethically right.}

21212709-d493-482c-81b6-364058169f9b.summary: Can knowledge guide action unsuccessfully due to external interference?
21212709-d493-482c-81b6-364058169f9b.content: {Consider a scenario where a person accurately knows the best route to a destination but encounters an unexpected roadblock. Intuitively, we would still claim that the person had knowledge, despite action being unsuccessful due to interference.}, {It is implausible that knowledge must entail successful action if external factors can unpredictably obstruct it.}

37a2413e-b2c6-4ef8-91ee-5b2d5b5686a2.summary: Is it possible to have knowledge without a specific action target?
37a2413e-b2c6-4ef8-91ee-5b2d5b5686a2.content: {There is a plausible principle that having knowledge about an abstract concept, like symmetry in nature, might involve understanding without any specific action being taken.}, {Consider a case in which an artist knows about the theory of perspective but does not yet apply it in their work. Intuitively, we would still say the artist possesses knowledge.}

5108b628-a5fb-4abb-a4e8-f3351b023732.summary: Does knowledge remain practical if it is second-hand?
5108b628-a5fb-4abb-a4e8-f3351b023732.content: {Suppose a person learns information from a reliable source but never personally applies it. Intuitively, we say the person knows the information, though it remains practically unutilized.}, {It is implausible to claim all knowledge must directly guide action if second-hand knowledge often informs but does not lead directly to action.}

12665b70-fbe4-4425-afd0-d75c6e939b15.summary: Can knowledge exist purely for understanding without altering behavior?
12665b70-fbe4-4425-afd0-d75c6e939b15.content: {Consider a case where a scientist knows facts about distant galaxies which do not alter their earthly behavior. Intuitively, we would ascribe knowledge to the scientist despite no direct action being taken.}, {It is implausible to argue that all knowledge leads to behavior changes if some serves to augment general understanding.}

a2b3562a-513d-47b9-b42e-e01e6928fcf7.summary: Can knowledge require an impossible infinite chain of reasons?
a2b3562a-513d-47b9-b42e-e01e6928fcf7.content: {It is implausible that an actual infinite chain of reasons is possible to possess by any finite human mind}, {Consider a scenario in which each reason requires another reason to justify it ad infinitum. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that a person could never complete this chain}, {An infinite regress of reasons seems to demand an infinite amount of time to fully comprehend, which is not feasible for a finite being}

d1a6a2cb-d329-4e87-a284-09d941f7a98b.summary: Does making belief a criterion for knowledge exclude justified but unconscious belief?
d1a6a2cb-d329-4e87-a284-09d941f7a98b.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has accurate, justified information stored in their memory but never consciously recalls it. Intuitively, we would judge this person as possessing knowledge}, {A person who implicitly understands a proposition without actively believing it at the moment still seems to have knowledge}, {It is implausible that momentary conscious belief is necessary for possessing knowledge}

b6bc1864-b6bf-47ab-a803-858eb67f7f78.summary: Is a true proposition ever known without belief?
b6bc1864-b6bf-47ab-a803-858eb67f7f78.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has abundant evidence about a proposition's truth but remains undecided in belief due to cautiousness. Intuitively, we might still claim that they possess knowledge}, {A true proposition with overwhelming evidence might be known even if its belief is temporarily suspended}, {Consider a scenario in which a person trusts a reliable expert's claim as knowledge without forming a personal belief. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that this reliance constitutes knowledge}

a288c493-dab9-42b0-86ef-841c5ffdb516.summary: Does infinite justification inadvertently regress into skepticism?
a288c493-dab9-42b0-86ef-841c5ffdb516.content: {Continuous demand for further justification leads to skepticism because knowledge never becomes conclusively justified}, {Consider a scenario where each justification leads to another question for justification, never allowing the issue to settle. Intuitively, this seems to negate the possibility of anyone ever truly knowing anything}, {It is implausible that a system requiring an infinite regress of reasons could adequately support claims of knowledge}

d9cb7fa2-e058-4e18-96d0-0d567feca38e.summary: Can all true beliefs lack knowledge without infinite reasons?
d9cb7fa2-e058-4e18-96d0-0d567feca38e.content: {A person who correctly forms beliefs about daily routines without elaborating on each reason seems to exemplify everyday knowledge}, {It is implausible that a belief about a proposition, based on everyday experience and context, requires an infinitely extensive chain of reasons to constitute knowledge}, {Consider a scenario in which a climax of evidence leads to a firm belief deemed knowledge despite no infinite chain. In such a scenario, intuitively we would still regard the belief as knowledge}

35557137-f1be-48bc-a03f-b8699482fcc8.summary: Does practical justification ever suffice for knowledge absent infinite reasons?
35557137-f1be-48bc-a03f-b8699482fcc8.content: {A person needing to act immediately in a circumstance, using what they already know without further reasons, seems to exemplify possessing knowledge even absent an infinite chain of reasons}, {It is implausible that practical situations demanding immediate action can wait for infinite justification to claim knowledge}, {Consider a scenario in which an emergency responder makes life-saving decisions based on prior training without conscious infinite reasoning. Intuitively, we would judge this as knowledge-driven action}

612fe576-6183-4d66-9ded-48904a6e0f46.summary: Can expertise contradict infinite justification for knowledge claims?
612fe576-6183-4d66-9ded-48904a6e0f46.content: {Consider a scenario where an expert gives an explanation that is accepted as knowledge due to their authority, despite limited explicit reasoning. Intuitively, we would judge this as a justified instance of knowledge}, {It is implausible to suppose that specialist knowledge requires independently running through an infinite set of justifications for an expert assertion to be known}, {A person's expertise in a field inherently entails shortcuts to conclusions normally requiring lengthy chains of reasoning}

42bf6856-6d5b-4727-a26e-050ae74a994f.summary: Can foundational beliefs truly need no further justification?
42bf6856-6d5b-4727-a26e-050ae74a994f.content: {A belief's justification is questionable if it rests on assumptions that themselves aren't justified.}, {A basic belief that isn't infallible raises doubts about the whole system of beliefs built upon it.}, {A self-evident proposition could still depend on implicit assumptions, challenging its foundational status.}

d2cbd2a8-e36d-4d4b-ae28-97bdde1c5299.summary: Can foundationalism adequately address the problem of disagreement?
d2cbd2a8-e36d-4d4b-ae28-97bdde1c5299.content: {If rational people can disagree on what is self-evident, the notion of self-evidence providing justification is problematic.}, {Disagreement among people with the same sensory evidence suggests that sensory evidence is not always reliably justifying.}, {The existence of reasonable disagreement about basic beliefs questions whether they truly require no further justification.}

4fae4d10-4035-4dff-9eda-cb59822b0e26.summary: Is there a coherent method to identify self-evident propositions?
4fae4d10-4035-4dff-9eda-cb59822b0e26.content: {No reliable criterion exists to universally identify self-evident propositions.}, {The claim that a proposition is self-evident can vary drastically between different individuals and cultures.}, {Without a clear method, calling a proposition self-evident becomes an arbitrary assertion.}

7702fb59-dd76-4903-b083-9112cf780533.summary: Are sensory perceptions always reliable sources of knowledge?
7702fb59-dd76-4903-b083-9112cf780533.content: {Sensory perceptions can be deceiving, such as in optical illusions, questioning their reliability as justifiers of knowledge.}, {Illusions and hallucinations are examples where sensory evidence might not reflect reality, challenging its trustworthiness.}, {Two individuals experiencing the same sensory input can arrive at contradictory beliefs, undermining the idea that sensory evidence alone justifies beliefs.}

f3399489-b5bd-4014-8e1b-c18568f7d3ee.summary: Does foundationalism address the problem of infinite regress in justification?
f3399489-b5bd-4014-8e1b-c18568f7d3ee.content: {Foundationalism seeks to halt infinite regress by positing basic beliefs, but questions arise about the justification of these basic beliefs themselves.}, {The impossibility of verifying the foundation of basic beliefs leads to skepticism about whether regress is truly stopped.}, {If basic beliefs are open to doubt, the system as a whole may still face an infinite regress of justification.}

0539f6ab-228b-4418-a200-16875acf30f3.summary: Can self-evident and sensory-evident propositions serve all domains of knowledge?
0539f6ab-228b-4418-a200-16875acf30f3.content: {Many domains of knowledge, such as mathematics and ethics, rely on principles not apparent through sensory perception or self-evidence.}, {Complex scientific theories often require inference beyond immediate sensory evidence, suggesting foundational limitations.}, {The use of abstract reasoning challenges the sufficiency of self-evident or sensory-evident propositions for foundational knowledge.}

fd0160ca-3a76-443f-a2c3-0e47c14b0d9f.summary: Is foundationalism vulnerable to the problem of circularity in justification?
fd0160ca-3a76-443f-a2c3-0e47c14b0d9f.content: {The attempt to claim a belief is self-evident might be circular if it serves merely to justify itself without any independent support.}, {Relying on sensory evidence for justification might assume what it seeks to prove, leading to circular reasoning.}, {The very distinction between basic and non-basic beliefs can rely on predefined assumptions, causing a potential circularity.}

c0d9a141-9088-4e8a-8b4f-2511545d8977.summary: How does foundationalism handle belief revision and error correction?
c0d9a141-9088-4e8a-8b4f-2511545d8977.content: {Basic beliefs that require no further justification pose a challenge for revising beliefs when confronted with error.}, {If foundational beliefs turn out to be mistaken, the entire structure of justified beliefs built on them is questioned.}, {Errors in beliefs taken to be self-evident or sensory-evident raise concerns about the rigidity and adaptability of foundationalism.}

9cd189bc-5f10-4e4f-9630-2a088b5a8658.content: {Doubt exists about whether any propositions can be so evident as to require no justification.}, {Historical shifts in what is considered self-evident suggest that such beliefs might not be timelessly so.}, {Different epistemic communities can identify different propositions as self-evident, implying their non-universality.}

28de5b55-53d7-4f12-b092-5495e64e0389.summary: Can foundational beliefs change over time, and if so, what does this mean for foundationalism?
28de5b55-53d7-4f12-b092-5495e64e0389.content: {What is considered a self-evident or sensory-evident proposition can change over time, challenging their foundational status.}, {The evolution of scientific paradigms shows that what was once sensory evidence can become outdated, casting doubt on its foundational reliability.}, {If foundational beliefs are subject to change, the stability and reliability of the entire epistemic structure is called into question.}

aac825b8-0029-4fb4-8c9e-216c114c4025.summary: Can coherence alone justify a belief?
aac825b8-0029-4fb4-8c9e-216c114c4025.content: {It is implausible that coherence alone among beliefs can constitute sufficient justification for a belief.}, {A case in which a person has a coherent system of beliefs all based on a falsehood does not intuitively provide justification for any of their beliefs.}

2c763a80-ab1b-4cad-94ea-191809c5e002.summary: Does coherence require truth for knowledge?
2c763a80-ab1b-4cad-94ea-191809c5e002.content: {A person can have a coherent system of beliefs where each belief is connected to the others, yet intuitively this does not mean the central belief is true.}, {A case in which a person believes in an internally coherent conspiracy theory does not intuitively result in knowledge of the conspiracy's occurrence.}

4ffe2daf-e71c-480a-881e-ecf707ab3339.summary: Can coherence exist without truth among beliefs?
4ffe2daf-e71c-480a-881e-ecf707ab3339.content: {It is implausible to assume that coherence among beliefs guarantees the truth of any individual belief.}, {A scenario where a set of interconnected but inaccurate reports within a community forms a coherent belief system does not intuitively result in the truth of those beliefs.}

e04c8c1d-b8b0-4f89-afcd-2b25155ac91f.summary: Is coherence sufficient for epistemic justification?
e04c8c1d-b8b0-4f89-afcd-2b25155ac91f.content: {A plausible principle is that beliefs must be grounded in reliable evidence for justification. This principle together with the requirement that coherence alone provides justification entails skepticism about knowledge derived solely from coherent belief systems.}, {A case where someone has coherent beliefs based on unreliable testimony does not provide intuitive justification.}

4c870eab-937b-4895-921e-60137bc0aecb.content: {Coherence allows for the possibility of a set of beliefs all being uniformly false.}, {A scenario in which a person develops a complete and coherent belief system based on fictional accounts does not result in true knowledge.}

c4104338-c53a-4c52-ab23-c9dbcdbc39e1.summary: Does coherence alone solve the Gettier problem?
c4104338-c53a-4c52-ab23-c9dbcdbc39e1.content: {A person can have a justified true belief that coheres with their system but still seem lacking in knowledge according to intuitive reactions to Gettier cases.}, {A scenario where a person believes all clocks stopped at 10am and happens to look at a working clock showing 10am does not intuitively provide knowledge despite coherence.}

c0d05eaf-a498-46a1-8a1f-f49220ffaa33.summary: Is there an objective measure of coherence?
c0d05eaf-a498-46a1-8a1f-f49220ffaa33.content: {There is a plausible principle that an objective standard must exist for assessing coherence for it to provide justification, yet it is implausible that such a definitive measure is available.}, {A system of beliefs appears coherent to one person but disjointed to another, questioning how coherence precisely justifies belief.}

ee82600d-7284-4466-93fe-7a1e581c3ec9.content: {A belief can be coherent yet require additional criteria such as reliability or evidence for its justification.}, {A plausible principle is that knowledge additionally requires belief alignment with reality to count as knowledge, challenging the sufficiency of coherence.}

a41a7fee-f79d-49fe-8ae4-fe2c18af828e.summary: Could coherence lead to circular reasoning?
a41a7fee-f79d-49fe-8ae4-fe2c18af828e.content: {Suppose we have a system in which all beliefs justify each other without external input. Intuitively, this raises concerns of circular justification, which lacks genuine epistemic grounding.}, {A network of mutually supporting but internally derived beliefs, like a closed loop, intuitively feels circular and unjustified.}

e0e8bf64-3391-45dd-9cf2-e520455e5a51.summary: Can coherent beliefs lead to false conclusions?
e0e8bf64-3391-45dd-9cf2-e520455e5a51.content: {A system of beliefs can be internally coherent yet lead to intuitive errors or false conclusions if based on initial inaccuracies.}, {A person consistently believes in and acts on a set of coherent but false beliefs due to an initial faulty premise does not achieve true knowledge.}

0e3740c9-4c64-4c4f-83d3-4779073d08b0.summary: Is coherence independent of empirical content?
0e3740c9-4c64-4c4f-83d3-4779073d08b0.content: {It is implausible for coherence alone to account for empirical content necessary in forming justified beliefs about the world.}, {A case where an individual has a perfectly coherent conceptual scheme divorced from empirical reality lacks intuitive justification.}

679a045b-d92c-4608-bac9-2a335528f586.summary: Does coherence account for perceptual beliefs?
679a045b-d92c-4608-bac9-2a335528f586.content: {A plausible principle is that perceptual beliefs require direct experiential evidence, which coherence cannot provide.}, {An individual's coherent belief about the color of an object based solely on hearsay lacks the direct perceptual input necessary for full justification.}

c7f1f158-378f-4e48-8089-87d9e9ff06bb.content: {A system based solely on coherence allows for multiple, incompatible, but self-consistent systems, raising doubts about its ability to deliver truth or knowledge.}, {Two individuals possessing internally coherent yet mutually exclusive belief systems seem equally justified in their views, raising issues about knowledge claims.}

6aaeef44-4713-4a85-a1a5-d0a77343e8f0.content: {Coherence among beliefs might be influenced by cognitive biases, thereby undermining the justification it appears to provide.}, {A case where confirmation bias leads to a coherent belief system, but it's driven by biased information processing, challenges its justification.}

e6c35cb0-0829-4de4-bbd5-58874dba51fd.summary: Does coherence address the problem of infinite regress?
e6c35cb0-0829-4de4-bbd5-58874dba51fd.content: {The requirement for coherence among beliefs may lead to an infinite regress, needing continual justification, which is implausible for forming practical knowledge.}, {A belief justified only by coherence with another requires that belief to likewise be justified, potentially ad infinitum.}

267a3009-e024-4dc2-ae0c-9368e12425dc.summary: Does evidentialism neglect the role of external factors in knowledge?
267a3009-e024-4dc2-ae0c-9368e12425dc.content: {A case in which a person has strong evidence for a proposition but it is accidentally true is not a case in which the person has knowledge.}, {External factors beyond mere evidence, such as the reliability of cognitive processes, may be necessary for knowledge.}

a39b3048-7e24-4e2e-80fc-64b20559f70d.summary: Can we have knowledge through testimony without direct evidence?
a39b3048-7e24-4e2e-80fc-64b20559f70d.content: {There are scenarios where a person knows a fact solely through testimony without having direct evidence.}, {A case in which someone is told that a city exists by a reliable source can result in knowledge even without the person verifying it directly.}

9d2988ed-7239-48e5-ad39-93eb49ffba16.summary: Can one know a proposition without conscious awareness of supporting evidence?
9d2988ed-7239-48e5-ad39-93eb49ffba16.content: {A plausible scenario is one where a person knows a proposition but cannot consciously recall the specific evidence supporting it.}, {Intuitively, a person might have knowledge because they have evidence stored in memory even if they cannot currently articulate it.}

41bcaa80-937c-4fba-a5b9-bec335bc6e0b.summary: Are all justified beliefs knowledge according to evidentialism?
41bcaa80-937c-4fba-a5b9-bec335bc6e0b.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person justifiably believes there is a table in the room based on clear evidence, but unbeknownst to them the perception is caused by an illusion.}, {Even if the belief is justified by apparent evidence, the lack of the table's actual existence implies the person does not truly have knowledge.}

7f6240c7-fb15-42c9-8e73-ed0e1e730195.summary: Does evidentialism fully account for the difference between truth and realistic scenarios of knowledge?
7f6240c7-fb15-42c9-8e73-ed0e1e730195.content: {A plausible principle states that knowing a proposition involves more than just its truth and supporting evidence.}, {Consider a situation where a person believes it will rain because of a reliable forecast, yet due to an unforeseeable meteorological anomaly, it does not rain—a case that challenges the straightforward link between evidence and truth in knowledge.}

8eabaa53-92a8-4d16-886c-6411800b4010.summary: Can knowledge exist with conflicting evidence?
8eabaa53-92a8-4d16-886c-6411800b4010.content: {Suppose there is a case where a person has evidence for the proposition that it will rain and contradictory evidence that it will not rain.}, {Intuitively, it is implausible that such a person knows the final outcome, despite holding evidence on both sides.}

b74943f4-2d16-4090-b13e-3c79ab86f32b.summary: Is there knowledge without evidence in the form of basic beliefs?
b74943f4-2d16-4090-b13e-3c79ab86f32b.content: {There is a plausible principle that some basic beliefs might be known without evidence, such as one's immediate awareness of their own mental states.}, {A person knowing they are in pain without needing evidence challenges the role evidence plays in all beliefs constituting knowledge.}

0a276021-7d74-45e3-9548-6fe04ad4f25c.summary: Can evidentialism account for knowledge that arises spontaneously?
0a276021-7d74-45e3-9548-6fe04ad4f25c.content: {Consider a scenario where a person suddenly realizes a solution to a problem without actively recalling the steps or evidence leading to it.}, {Intuitively, this realization seems like a form of knowledge, even if evidence is not being consciously cited.}

43132014-59c2-4ce8-8ef5-8a44892bd536.summary: Does evidentialism overlook the importance of coherence in belief systems?
43132014-59c2-4ce8-8ef5-8a44892bd536.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person's belief is supported by isolated pieces of evidence but does not fit coherently within their broader belief system.}, {Without coherence, the belief might attain reasoned support but lacks the quality of being known.}

35909c97-75ab-406b-8270-9a0a94f81881.summary: Can one have evidence but still lack understanding?
35909c97-75ab-406b-8270-9a0a94f81881.content: {A plausible principle is that knowledge also requires understanding, which is more than mere evidence.}, {A case in which one memorizes facts without comprehending them suggests that evidence alone does not suffice for knowledge.}

07d1a66d-1e61-48dc-91f2-5a6b24c8ed5b.summary: Does external evidence challenge internal access to justification?
07d1a66d-1e61-48dc-91f2-5a6b24c8ed5b.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person forms a belief that a storm is approaching by observing dark clouds and hearing weather forecasts. The person has introspective access to these reasons. However, if unknown to them, the equipment used for the forecast is broken and the dark clouds are unrelated to any storm activity, then their justification is only externally accessible. Intuitively, we would judge that the person lacks appropriate justification for their belief, indicating that not all justification is internally accessible.}

f3298e73-d0af-4ed4-86fd-ce879ef869ca.summary: Is internalism undermined by the possibility of forgotten evidence?
f3298e73-d0af-4ed4-86fd-ce879ef869ca.content: {Suppose a person once obtained strong evidence for a certain belief but later forgets the nature of the evidence itself while retaining the belief. The internal accessibility of justification requires that the person can access reasons for their belief directly. Intuitively, if the person can no longer recall the evidence, the justification is not internally accessible, yet it seems incorrect to say they lack justification entirely. This suggests a gap in the internalist account of justification.}

57b28ea2-e437-45bc-9014-ef449774c7bf.summary: Do cognitive limitations pose a problem for internal access to justification?
57b28ea2-e437-45bc-9014-ef449774c7bf.content: {Suppose an individual holds a belief based on evidence that was once internally accessible but is now rendered inaccessible due to cognitive decline or a memory disorder. The notion of internal accessibility posits that justification must always be available to the believer's introspection. However, intuitively, the person's condition implies that justification they once had remains just as valid even if they cannot currently access it, challenging the idea that justification must always be readily accessible.}

cc3d1149-47e7-43f3-8be9-e6b7233e32b4.summary: Can the New Evil Demon Problem refute internalism?
cc3d1149-47e7-43f3-8be9-e6b7233e32b4.content: {Consider a scenario where a person lives in a world controlled by a malicious demon who deceives them about external evidence. Despite lacking true external evidence, the person believes they have justification based on internally accessible reasons they perceive. This suggests that justification must be internally accessible even in cases where external truth is manipulated, but intuitively, it seems incorrect to suggest the person is truly justified. The New Evil Demon Problem indicates that purely internal accessibility may not account for scenarios of radical deception related to justification.}

e2e69607-a738-42b1-8417-1b51c8d40b40.summary: Does reliabilism offer a counterexample to internal justification?
e2e69607-a738-42b1-8417-1b51c8d40b40.content: {Suppose a person's belief is formed by a reliable cognitive process, such as a well-functioning perceptual system, and is consistently aligned with truth despite the person being unaware of the process itself. Reliabilism argues that justification pertains to the reliability of processes used to form beliefs. Intuitively, the belief seems justified if it consistently matches reality, yet the internalism view faces difficulty if such justification is not internally accessible to the person.}

eee26819-22b9-4732-80ed-5334d6e3af50.summary: Does memory-based knowledge challenge internal access to justification?
eee26819-22b9-4732-80ed-5334d6e3af50.content: {Imagine a person who believes a mathematical theorem based on a complex proof they once understood. Though they forget parts of the proof over time, they retain confidence in the theorem's truth. The principle of internal accessibility holds that the person should have direct access to all justificatory reasons. However, intuition suggests that the person remains justified in their belief even if internal access to every aspect of the justification is lost, questioning the necessity of constant internal availability of reasons.}

908628a4-3b8a-4185-9816-e8ff98d113e6.summary: Does the problem of epistemic circularity undermine internalism?
908628a4-3b8a-4185-9816-e8ff98d113e6.content: {Suppose a person uses perceptual evidence to justify the reliability of their perceptual beliefs. Internalists argue that justification is based on internally accessible factors. However, epistemic circularity arises because using perception to justify perception seems intuitively flawed, suggesting a kind of dependence on external criteria for justification that internalism does not fully account for. This highlights potential limitations in the internalist framework concerning how assurance in belief reliability is acquired and justified.}

8236590f-9ba0-4d56-9428-b8e1f4527fa0.summary: Can external factors alone ensure justification for true beliefs?
8236590f-9ba0-4d56-9428-b8e1f4527fa0.content: {Consider a scenario where a person believes a true proposition based on unreliable testimony from a known habitual liar. Intuitively, this is not a case of knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that justification for knowledge must involve reliable cognitive processes. Relying on such processes would preclude claiming justification from unreliable sources.}

8a79d0cc-1365-4923-a7c6-8b7b344a279c.summary: Is belief sufficient for knowledge without understanding?
8a79d0cc-1365-4923-a7c6-8b7b344a279c.content: {Imagine a situation where a person memorizes a true scientific fact without understanding it, solely based on an authoritative individual's statement. It seems counterintuitive to consider this knowledge.}, {It is implausible that mere belief, even if true, without a comprehension component constitutes knowledge.}

6d85a7e7-f82f-4261-bf27-eaf13451001a.summary: Can external factors justify irrational beliefs?
6d85a7e7-f82f-4261-bf27-eaf13451001a.content: {Suppose there is a case where a person believes a fact because of being under pressure from an authority figure. This belief turns out to be correct but lacks rational basis. Intuitively, this doesn't seem to be knowledge.}, {A plausible principle is that knowledge must exclude beliefs formed via coercion or irrational influence, even if those beliefs are externally justified.}

0f5ffc28-e09d-4394-a54e-44da7abad9dd.summary: Does knowing require epistemic responsibility beyond true belief?
0f5ffc28-e09d-4394-a54e-44da7abad9dd.content: {Consider a scenario where a person forms a true belief about the weather by simply guessing. This belief lacks responsibility and considered assessment. Intuitively, such cases do not represent knowledge.}, {A principle that knowledge involves epistemic responsibility suggests that true belief alone, even if externally justified, is insufficient.}

5ac6f330-4f0f-4210-89db-12efb4922e69.summary: Can externalism account for the role of skepticism?
5ac6f330-4f0f-4210-89db-12efb4922e69.content: {Imagine a situation where a person believes in a proposition solely because it's widely accepted, without personal validation. This reliance on consensus generates skepticism regarding true belief.}, {It is implausible to reconcile external justifications with personal skepticism about truth. Knowledge should withstand skeptical doubts about mere consensus.}

fb8893f3-9e9e-4846-ba62-db6b62e33777.summary: Can false information count as knowledge?
fb8893f3-9e9e-4846-ba62-db6b62e33777.content: {A person believes a proposition that is false but is consistent with all the person's currently held true beliefs.}, {Intuitively, a person cannot be said to know a false proposition, even if it fits with their existing information.}, {Knowledge requires truth, so adding a false proposition does not count as adding to one's store of knowledge.}

3435fa72-a991-48d0-84a3-3302c7d67a89.content: {A person has information that was once true but has since been proven false.}, {Intuitively, this outdated information cannot be considered knowledge now, even if it once added to the person's store of information.}, {Knowledge is not static and must remain in accordance with current facts and truths.}

9e5a465b-0bf7-4a01-984e-9d97f0ff5840.summary: Does all true information count as knowledge?
9e5a465b-0bf7-4a01-984e-9d97f0ff5840.content: {A person overhears a rumor that turns out to be true by coincidence.}, {Intuitively, the person does not have knowledge because the truth of the rumor was not established through a reliable method.}, {Knowledge requires not just true information, but also justified belief based on adequate evidence or reason.}

62008255-2727-42ef-872e-8806a4982ce2.summary: Can one possess knowledge without awareness?
62008255-2727-42ef-872e-8806a4982ce2.content: {A person is in possession of information stored in their brain that they cannot consciously access.}, {Intuitively, having information that you are not aware of does not seem to meet the criteria for knowledge.}, {Knowledge implies some level of conscious access and understanding of the information.}

2dad8e58-b6ff-4577-ab47-20c2caa5d195.summary: Is unreliable but true information knowledge?
2dad8e58-b6ff-4577-ab47-20c2caa5d195.content: {A person believes a proposition based on an unreliable source, which happens to be true.}, {Intuitively, without reliability, we hesitate to label this as knowledge due to the source's untrustworthiness.}, {Knowledge involves a degree of reliability in how information is acquired or justified.}

0a005ff0-45b3-4b3c-8d47-c49224b9ccd2.summary: What about knowledge that isn't informative?
0a005ff0-45b3-4b3c-8d47-c49224b9ccd2.content: {A person already knows every proposition related to a true fact and thus gains no new information by learning it.}, {Intuitively, this does not add to their store of information, raising the question of whether it still counts as knowledge.}, {Knowledge might involve not just true information, but also an element of cognitive gain or novelty.}

ac2f58b7-31a7-4143-a56b-4f34f4282170.summary: Is partial information sufficient for knowledge?
ac2f58b7-31a7-4143-a56b-4f34f4282170.content: {A person has fragmented and incomplete but true information about a particular subject.}, {Intuitively, this poses an issue as knowledge might imply having comprehensive understanding, not just snippets of truth.}, {Knowledge could entail a holistic grasp of context, not just isolated facts.}

fd485b02-1048-4110-a320-3016d9c78eb5.summary: Can inconsistent beliefs coexist with knowledge?
fd485b02-1048-4110-a320-3016d9c78eb5.content: {A person holds two true beliefs that are mutually inconsistent without being aware of the inconsistency.}, {Intuitively, this inconsistency creates doubt about whether either belief constitutes genuine knowledge.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among beliefs for them to be part of an informational store.}

3ab740c6-9d88-425a-9160-d2cfddb65c33.content: {A person exhibits practical skills or know-how that cannot be expressed in propositional form.}, {Intuitively, these skills seem like a form of knowledge, challenging the notion that all knowledge is propositional.}, {Knowledge could include procedural or practical forms not reducible to simple true propositions.}

4a271320-e681-4add-a792-cae8b8beff51.summary: Can a false perception directly provide knowledge?
4a271320-e681-4add-a792-cae8b8beff51.content: {A hallucination without external input is indistinguishable from a true perception for the perceiver.}, {If a hallucination seems real, intuitively we would treat it as not providing knowledge.}

48843543-9ece-4106-ab9d-0aae5d1f0953.summary: Do accurate perceptions always lead to knowledge?
48843543-9ece-4106-ab9d-0aae5d1f0953.content: {An accurate perception that aligns with reality can still lead to false beliefs if misinterpreted.}, {Intuitively, misinterpretation due to cognitive biases leads to a lack of knowledge despite accurate perception.}
